align_transcripts.py - multiply align transcripts¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

This script will multiply align transcripts. Transcripts are aligned as amino acid sequences and later back-translated to codon sequences.

The script is aware of gene structures will correctly align exons in sequence.

If there are multiple transcripts for a gene, concatenate the exons into one pseudo-transcript and submit that to the multiple alignment in order to avoid incompatible exons to be aligned. After alignment, the pseudo-transcripts are split into separate parts again.

If the peptide sequence contains at least one character U, the sequence is assumed to be selonoprotein.

Usage¶

Example:

python align_transcripts.py --help

Type:

python align_transcripts.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: align_transcripts.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  -m MASTER, --master=MASTER
                        master sequence.
  -p MASTER_PATTERN, --master-pattern=MASTER_PATTERN
                        master pattern.
  --master-species=MASTER_SPECIES
                        species to use as master sequences.
  -t FILENAME_TRANSLATION, --translate=FILENAME_TRANSLATION
                        filename on where to store translated sequences.
  -e FILENAME_EXONS, --exons=FILENAME_EXONS
                        filename on where to exon information.
  -g FILENAME_GTF, --gtf=FILENAME_GTF
                        filename with exon information in gtf format.
  -c, --mark-codons     mark codons.
  --remove-stops        remove stop codons.
  --mask-stops          mask stop codons.
  --mask-char=MASK_CHAR
                        masking character to use.
  -f, --remove-frameshifts
                        remove columns corresponding to frameshifts.
  -s, --split-exons     split columns aligned to different exons in the same
                        gene.
  -a TARGET, --target=TARGET
                        perform cleaning up for certain targets.
  --stop-at=STOP_AT     stop at intermediate stage and dump out that
                        alignment.
  --force-map           force mapping of sequences that have changed to
                        previous sequence.
  --cds=FILENAME_CDS    filename with cds - useful if you expect pseudogenes
                        in your set. The peptide
                        sequences will be aligned to the cds sequences. This
                        produces better coordinates.
  --output=OUTPUT       which alignment to output: aligned=aligned sequences,
                        but before untangling exons;  final=final multiple
                        alignment; unaligned=unaligned sequences;
                        coords=genomic coordinates (corresponding to
                        'final_na').
  --output-filename-pattern=OUTPUT_FILENAME_PATTERN
                        filename pattern for multiple alignment output files.
                        If no --output option is given, stdout is used.
  --output-filename-coords=OUTPUT_FILENAME_COORDS
                        filename to output coordinates to.
  --output-format=OUTPUT_FORMAT
                        output format of multiple alignments.
  --strict              apply strict checking.
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
